article.description: Chris Hill totaled 18 points, seven rebounds and seven assists to lead the 15th-ranked Spartans to their fourth straight victory, 80-54 over the Ramblers.
article.headline: Izzo, Spartans feel they 'went through the motions'
article.linkText: Izzo also miffed as MSU romps past Loyola-Chicago
article.story: EAST LANSING, Mich. (AP) -- Michigan State didn't suffer a letdown on the scoreboard. But it did in the eyes of Spartans coach Tom Izzo. Chris Hill had 18 points, seven rebounds and seven assists as No. 15 Michigan State beat Loyola of Chicago 80-54 Tuesday night for its 34th consecutive win over a non-conference opponent at home. While the end result looked like the Spartans (6-2) responded well to their win Saturday at Kentucky -- with their fourth straight victory -- Izzo didn't think they did. "I hate these stat sheets because when you look at them, they look pretty good, but I'm extremely disappointed,'' Izzo said. "I'm going to tell it like it is. And if somebody doesn't like that, that's too bad. "This team did not grow. Don't pat them on the back for the Kentucky win if they're not able to handle it. We must have thought we won the world championship.'' The Spartans led from the start, and had a double-digit lead for more than half the game. But they couldn't pull away until midway through the second half. A 10-1 run gave the Spartans a 63-44 lead with 8:32 left. Alan Anderson and Erazem Lorbek added 12 points each for Michigan State, which also got 11 from Paul Davis and 10 from Kelvin Torbert. Hill, who was 6-of-11 from the field, said Izzo wasn't the only one disappointed with the 26-point win. "Our main goal was to play with the same intensity that we did at Kentucky, and we didn't,'' Hill said. "We got away with going through the motions for this game, but we have to play with a much better effort to reach our ultimate goals of winning championships.'' David Bailey scored 15 points for the Ramblers (4-4), and Paul McMillan added 14. Loyola coach Larry Farmer was not startled that Izzo was angry. "Nobody knows this team better than he does,'' Farmer said. "And if he's not happy with some of the things they did, maybe he's just trying to get them better.'' That's exactly what Izzo is trying to do, and he's used similar tactics in the past after lopsided wins. "This team has a chance to be very good, and this team has a chance to be average,'' Izzo said. "I'm looking for very good. Right now, they're looking for average. Somewhere in the middle we're going to meet, and we're going to see who wins. "Don't be fooled by Kentucky. We beat a good team. Big deal. If we're going to be satisfied with that win, then this program has taken three steps backward.'' Michigan State didn't help its hopes for an early rout because of uncharacteristic struggles at the free-throw line. It began the game making 77.7 percent, but converted just 15-of-28 against Loyola. "That is a lack of focus,'' Izzo said. As Izzo reluctantly acknowledged, the Spartans looked good on the stat sheet. Michigan State made 20 assists, with just 11 turnovers, won the rebounding battle 45-31 and held Loyola to 36.1 percent shooting. "We're disappointed, particularly with our shooting and rebounding,'' Farmer said. The Spartans got off to a good start with a 17-7 lead, but Loyola quickly pulled within four points. Michigan State led 34-25 at halftime and scored the first seven points after the break. But the Ramblers to cut the deficit to 53-43 before the Spartans went on their decisive run.
